title: Window Washing — Introduction
description: The child learns to wash a window or mirror using a spray bottle and squeegee. This satisfying care of environment activity develops bilateral coordination, sequencing skills, and the ability to see and correct one's own work.
instructions:
1. Present materials on a tray: spray bottle with water (add a drop of vinegar), small squeegee, soft cloth, bucket.
2. Demonstrate: spray the window 2-3 times with even coverage.
3. 'Now we use the squeegee: start at the top, pull DOWN in one smooth stroke.' Wipe the squeegee blade with the cloth after each pass.
4. 'Overlap your strokes slightly so you do not leave streaks.'
5. 'Dry the edges and bottom with the cloth.'
6. 'Step back and look — is it clean? Hold it up to the light to check for streaks.'
materials_needed: Small spray bottle (water with a drop of vinegar)
Small bucket or tray for drips

slides.setup_instructions: Fill spray bottle with water and a drop of vinegar. Choose a low window or a mirror at child height. Protect the floor with a towel.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to make our window SPARKLE! When windows are clean, more light comes in and we can see the world clearly.'
Demonstrate spraying: 'Hold the spray bottle with both hands. Squeeze the handle — spray, spray, spray. Cover the whole window with a fine mist.'
'Now the squeegee: start at the TOP. Pull DOWN in one smooth stroke.' Demonstrate. 'Wipe the blade with the cloth. Then the next stripe — overlap a little.'
'Dry the edges and bottom with the cloth. Now step back and look — hold it up to the light. Any streaks? Go over those spots again!'

slides.prompt: Wash the window yourself! Spray, squeegee from top to bottom, wipe the edges. Step back and check your work — can you see through clearly? Fix any streaks.

slides.text: Clean up: empty excess water, wipe the tray, hang the cloth to dry. 'Look at that clean window! YOU did that!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child spray evenly, use the squeegee from top to bottom, and evaluate their own work for streaks?

parent_notes: Window washing is a favorite Montessori activity because it offers immediate visible results and a built-in control of error — the child can SEE streaks and dirty spots and correct them independently. The squeegee technique requires bilateral coordination (one hand holds the squeegee, the other wipes the blade) and top-to-bottom sequencing. Start with a mirror at child height if windows are too high. The spray bottle itself is wonderful for hand strength development — the repeated squeezing action strengthens the same muscles used for writing. A tiny amount of vinegar in the water creates a streak-free solution. Let the child wash the same window multiple times if they enjoy it; repetition is how mastery develops.

title: Phonogram Review and New Words — sh, ch, th
description: The child reviews all three phonograms and reads an expanded list of words containing them. This lesson focuses on building fluency through word lists, sentence reading, and the introduction of phonogram word families.
instructions:
1. Review phonogram cards: /sh/, /ch/, /th/. Child traces and says each sound.
2. Present word lists organized by phonogram:
   - sh: shell, shut, shock, shrug, slash, brush, gush, blush
   - ch: chick, check, church, bench, bunch, branch, crunch
   - th: thick, thump, throb, teeth, month, cloth, growth
3. Child reads through each list, sounding out carefully.
4. 'Some of these words have BLENDS too: br-ush, cr-unch, thr-ob.'
5. Dictation: say a word, child builds it with moveable alphabet.
6. Read 3 sentences using these words.
materials_needed: Word list cards organized by phonogram

slides.heading: Phonogram Review
slides.subheading: Building Fluency with sh, ch, th

slides.setup_instructions: Organize words by phonogram on separate cards or strips. Have the moveable alphabet ready for dictation.

slides.text: 'Let's warm up our phonogram brains! What does s-h say? C-h? T-h?' Quick review with cards. 'Perfect! Now let's read some new words.'
Present the sh list: shell, shut, shock, brush, blush. 'Some of these are longer. Sound through them slowly: sh-e-ll. shell!'
Present the ch list: chick, check, bench, crunch. 'Notice: ch can be at the beginning OR the end of a word!'
Present the th list: thick, thump, teeth, cloth. 'Some have TH at the start, some at the end. Your eyes need to spot the letter team wherever it is!'

slides.prompt: Read through all three word lists. Then dictation: I say a word, you build it with the moveable alphabet. Try: brush, bench, teeth, shell, church, month. Read each back to check!

slides.text: 'You are reading longer and more complex words now! Phonograms open up SO many words in English.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 8 phonogram words fluently and build 4 from dictation?

parent_notes: This review and extension lesson consolidates the three phonograms before moving forward. Words are getting longer and more complex — many include consonant blends (br, cr, thr) alongside phonograms. This is natural progression: the child combines multiple phonetic strategies simultaneously. Dictation (parent says word, child builds it) is particularly valuable because it requires the child to segment sounds, identify phonograms by ear, and translate sounds to letters. If the child struggles with a word, break it into parts: 'cr-u-nch — what do you hear first? cr. Then? u. Then? nch — that ends with our /ch/!' The word lists can be kept for repeated reading practice; fluency comes from rereading familiar words until they become automatic.

title: Golden Beads — Addition with Exchange
description: The child performs golden bead addition where one or more categories sum to more than 9, requiring an exchange. This is the concrete foundation for 'carrying' in written addition.
instructions:
1. Review the exchange rule: '10 of one thing becomes 1 of the next bigger thing.'
2. Set up: first addend is 1,456. Second addend is 2,387.
3. Combine by category. Units: 6+7=13 units. 'We have 13 units! That is more than 9! We must EXCHANGE!'
4. Count 10 units, exchange for 1 ten bar. Place the ten bar with the tens. 3 units remain.
5. Tens: 5+8+1(exchanged)=14 tens. Exchange 10 tens for 1 hundred. 4 tens remain.
6. Continue through hundreds and thousands. Build answer: 3,843.
7. 'The exchanges made some categories bigger!'

slides.setup_instructions: Choose addends that require exchange in at least one category. Have extra beads available for the exchange process.

slides.text: 'Last time we added and each group had 9 or fewer. Today something exciting happens — we will need to EXCHANGE!'
Set up: 'I have 1,456. You have 2,387. Let's put them together!' Combine units first: 6 + 7 = 13 units.
'Thirteen units! But we can only have 9 units in the units place. We have MORE than 9! What do we do?' Child: 'Exchange!' Count 10 units → 1 ten bar. 3 units stay.
Tens: 5 + 8 = 13, plus the 1 exchanged = 14 tens. 'More than 9 tens! Exchange 10 tens for 1 hundred.' 4 tens stay. Continue for hundreds.

slides.prompt: Try this addition: 3,275 + 1,468. Combine beads by category, exchange whenever you get more than 9 in any group. Build your answer with number cards!

slides.text: 'Addition with exchange! When you have more than 9 in any group, you exchange 10 for 1 of the next bigger thing. This is how real addition works!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform golden bead addition with at least one exchange, correctly carrying to the next category?

parent_notes: Addition with exchange is a major milestone — the child is performing the same operation that will later be written as 'carrying' in the standard algorithm. But because they are doing it with physical beads, they UNDERSTAND why carrying works: you literally gather 10 smaller pieces and trade them for 1 larger piece. The exchange process should feel natural because the child has already practiced exchange games. Choose addends that require exchange in only 1-2 categories at first, then increase complexity. Some children initially forget to add the exchanged piece to the next category — place it visibly with that group immediately after exchanging. This lesson may need to be repeated several times before the child is fluent.

title: Land and Water Forms — Archipelago and Lake System
description: The child learns two new land and water form pairs: archipelago (a chain of islands) and a system of lakes. Building on the previously learned pairs, these more complex forms expand geographic vocabulary and understanding.
instructions:
1. Review previously learned pairs: island/lake, peninsula/gulf, isthmus/strait, cape/bay.
2. Present new pair: ARCHIPELAGO — 'A group or chain of islands. Like stepping stones in the ocean!'
3. Show examples: Hawaii, Philippines, Indonesia, Japan.
4. Present the paired form: a SYSTEM OF LAKES — 'Several lakes connected together, like the Great Lakes.'
5. Create clay models of an archipelago in a pan of water.
6. Label and add to the land/water form booklet.

slides.setup_instructions: Have clay and a pan ready for model building. Print or display pictures of famous archipelagos.

slides.text: 'Remember our land and water forms? Island, peninsula, isthmus, cape... Today we learn a big new word: ARCHIPELAGO!' Say it slowly: ar-chi-PEL-a-go.
'An archipelago is a CHAIN of islands — many islands in a row or group!' Show Hawaii on the map: 'Hawaii is an archipelago — a chain of islands in the Pacific Ocean!'
Show more examples: 'Japan is an archipelago. Indonesia is the biggest archipelago in the world — over 17,000 islands!' Point them out on the globe.
'The pair of an archipelago is a SYSTEM OF LAKES — many lakes connected together, like the Great Lakes between the US and Canada.'

slides.prompt: Build an archipelago with clay in the pan of water! Make 4-5 small islands in a chain. Pour water around them. Label your model. Then draw and label the archipelago in your booklet.

slides.text: 'An archipelago is a chain of islands. People in archipelagos often use boats to travel between islands! Can you say archipelago?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define archipelago, give an example, and create a model?

parent_notes: Children love the word 'archipelago' — it sounds impressive and they enjoy saying it! This is a perfect example of the Montessori principle of not underestimating children's ability to learn sophisticated vocabulary. The clay model makes the concept concrete: the child literally builds islands in water and sees how an archipelago forms. The land/water form pairs are a Montessori hallmark: every land form has a corresponding water form (island/lake, peninsula/gulf, archipelago/system of lakes). This dual presentation helps the child understand that land and water define each other. Real-world connections are powerful: if you live near any islands, relate the lesson to your local geography.

title: Read-Aloud: Owl Moon by Jane Yolen
description: Reading Jane Yolen's Caldecott-winning story about a child and father who go owling on a winter night. The lyrical text and stunning illustrations celebrate patience, wonder, and the bond between parent and child in nature.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a story about a child who goes out at night with their father to look for owls. Have you ever been outside at night?'
2. Read slowly — this book deserves a quiet, reverent pace.
3. Pause at the beautiful descriptions: 'The trees stood still as giant statues.'
4. When they finally see the owl: 'They waited and hoped, and finally... the owl came!'
5. Discuss: 'What did the child have to do? Be patient. Be quiet. Be hopeful.'
6. Listen for night sounds: 'What sounds might you hear outside at night?'
materials_needed: Optional: dim lighting to create a nighttime atmosphere

slides.setup_instructions: Create a quiet, cozy atmosphere. Dim the lights if possible — this is a nighttime story.

slides.text: 'This story happens on a cold winter night. A child and their father go out into the woods to find an owl. Let's go with them.'
Read slowly and softly, matching the quiet mood. The text is poetic: 'Somewhere behind us a train whistle blew, long and low, like a sad, sad song.'
Pause at the owl's appearance. The child and father have been so patient. 'There it was — a Great Horned Owl! All that waiting was worth it.'

slides.prompt: After reading: 'The child learned that going owling means you have to be quiet, patient, and hopeful. What is something YOU have been patient for? Was it worth the wait?'

slides.text: 'When you go owling, you do not need words or warmth or anything but hope. Sometimes the most beautiful things come to those who wait quietly.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe what owling requires (patience, quiet, hope) and retell what happened in the story?

parent_notes: Owl Moon is one of the finest picture books ever written, with John Schoenherr's luminous illustrations perfectly complementing Jane Yolen's poetic text. Read it slowly — this book should not be rushed. The themes of patience, perseverance, and the rewards of quiet observation align perfectly with Montessori values. If possible, take a night walk with your child after reading. You may not see an owl, but the experience of being outside in darkness, listening to night sounds, is powerful. The father-child relationship in the book is tender and wordless — they communicate through shared experience. This is a beautiful model for the parent-child bond in homeschooling.

title: Constructive Triangles — First Box (Blue)
description: The child works with the blue constructive triangles, discovering that different triangle combinations create new geometric shapes. This exercise develops spatial reasoning and the understanding that triangles are the fundamental building blocks of geometry.
instructions:
1. Open the blue constructive triangles box.
2. Remove all triangles and lay them scattered on the mat.
3. 'Each triangle has a black line on one side. When we match black lines together, we make new shapes!'
4. Demonstrate: take two right-angled triangles, match their black lines. 'A rectangle!'
5. Try another pair: two equal triangles form a larger triangle.
6. Another pair forms a square. Another forms a parallelogram.
7. Child works independently to match all pairs and name resulting shapes.

slides.setup_instructions: Place all triangles from the box scattered on a mat. The black lines guide matching.

slides.text: 'Triangles are amazing shapes — when we put them together, they can become OTHER shapes! These triangles have black lines that show us how to match them.'
Pick up two matching right-angled triangles. 'See the black lines? When we put them together...' Join the black lines. 'What shape did we make? A RECTANGLE!'
Try another pair: 'These two make a SQUARE!' And another: 'A PARALLELOGRAM — that is a fancy word for a leaning rectangle!'
'And look — two triangles can even make a BIGGER triangle!' Show equal isosceles triangles joining to form a larger triangle.

slides.prompt: Match all the pairs by their black lines. How many different shapes can you create? Name each one: rectangle, square, triangle, parallelogram. Can you make them all?

slides.text: 'Triangles are the building blocks of ALL shapes! Every rectangle, square, and diamond can be split into triangles.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match triangle pairs and name at least 3 resulting shapes?

parent_notes: The constructive triangles reveal a fundamental geometric truth: any polygon can be decomposed into triangles. This is why triangles are considered the basic building block of geometry. The black lines serve as a control of error — they guide the child to correct pairings. Once mastered with lines, future boxes remove the lines, and the child must figure out combinations purely by shape and size. If you do not have the official material, cut matching triangle pairs from colored cardstock and add guiding lines with a marker. The vocabulary — rectangle, square, parallelogram, rhombus — is rich, and children absorb these terms naturally when they arise from hands-on discovery rather than abstract definitions.

title: Grammar Introduction — The Noun
description: The child is introduced to the concept of a noun: a word that names a person, place, or thing. Using a Montessori black triangle symbol and concrete objects, the child identifies nouns in their environment and in sentences.
instructions:
1. 'Words have different JOBS in a sentence. Today we learn about words that NAME things.'
2. Hold up an apple. 'What is this? An apple. APPLE is the NAME of this thing. Naming words are called NOUNS.'
3. Point to objects: table, chair, window, book. 'These are all nouns — names of things!'
4. Show the black triangle symbol: 'In Montessori, we use a black triangle to mark nouns.'
5. Write simple phrases on strips: 'the red ball,' 'a tall tree.' Child places the black triangle over each noun.
6. 'People are nouns too! Mom, Dad, teacher, friend. And places: park, school, kitchen.'
materials_needed: Small objects to label (apple, book, cup, ball)

slides.setup_instructions: Cut large black triangles from paper. Write simple phrases on strips. Have several objects on a tray.

slides.text: 'Every word in a sentence has a JOB. Some words NAME things. Hold up this apple — the word APPLE is a NAMING word. We call naming words NOUNS.'
Point around the room: 'Table — noun! Chair — noun! Window — noun! Book — noun! Nouns are everywhere because EVERYTHING has a name!'
Show the black triangle: 'This is the symbol for a noun. Whenever we find a noun, we put a black triangle above it.' Place one over the word 'apple.'
Read a phrase strip: 'the red ball.' 'Which word is the noun — the naming word? BALL!' Place the black triangle over 'ball.'

slides.prompt: Read each phrase strip and find the noun. Place the black triangle over it. Then walk around the room and label 5 objects with word cards. Every label is a noun!

slides.text: 'Nouns are naming words — they name people, places, and things. You are surrounded by nouns! A noun answers the question: WHAT IS IT?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define a noun, identify nouns in phrases, and label objects as nouns?

parent_notes: The Montessori approach to grammar is concrete and sensorial. Rather than defining parts of speech abstractly, the child handles objects, reads words, and places physical symbols. The large black triangle for nouns has a reason: in Montessori symbolism, the triangle represents the oldest, most stable part of speech (things existed before actions or descriptions). The black color represents the dense, solid nature of things. This may seem overly symbolic, but children absorb these associations effortlessly. The Farm Game is a traditional Montessori grammar activity: write noun labels for everything on a table or in a room, and the child places them. This makes nouns tangible. Grammar study will continue with verbs (red circles) in future lessons.

title: Golden Beads — Addition Practice with Exchange
description: The child practices golden bead addition with exchange, building fluency with the process. Multiple addition problems reinforce the sequence: combine by category, check for exchanges, count the result, and compose the answer.
instructions:
1. 'Let's practice more addition! Remember: combine, check for exchanges, count, and build your answer.'
2. Problem 1: 2,345 + 1,276 (exchange in units: 5+6=11, and tens: 4+7+1=12)
3. Problem 2: 3,158 + 4,563 (exchange in units: 8+3=11, hundreds: 1+5+1=7, no exchange)
4. For each problem, child fetches beads, combines, exchanges, counts, and builds answer with cards.
5. Verify each answer together.
6. Child may create their own addition problem to solve.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up for multiple addition problems. Have the bead bank well-stocked for exchanges.

slides.text: 'You know how to add with golden beads AND exchange! Today we practice to get even better. The steps are: combine, check, exchange, count, build!'
Problem 1: '2,345 + 1,276. Build both numbers with beads and cards. Now combine!' Units: 5+6=11. 'More than 9 — exchange!' 1 ten bar, 1 unit stays.
Tens: 4+7=11, plus 1 from exchange = 12. 'Exchange again!' 1 hundred square, 2 ten bars stay. Continue counting hundreds and thousands.
Build the answer with cards. 'Check: does our bead quantity match our number cards? Yes! Let's do another!'

slides.prompt: Solve these additions with golden beads: 3,158 + 4,563. Then make up your OWN addition problem — choose two numbers, build them, and add! What answer do you get?

slides.text: 'You are getting faster and more confident with addition! The exchange rule always works the same way — 10 of one becomes 1 of the next.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently perform golden bead addition with exchange, completing at least 2 problems?

parent_notes: Practice is essential for fluency with golden bead operations. Each time the child performs an addition, the process becomes more automatic: combine, check each category for exchanges, count the result. Let the child create their own problems — this is more motivating than always following assigned numbers. If the child wants to add very large numbers (like 9,999 + 9,999), embrace it! They will discover the need for a ten-thousand category (which the golden beads do not include), opening a conversation about bigger numbers. Some children prefer to work with a partner, each person holding one addend — this social element mirrors the traditional Montessori classroom where children work in small groups for golden bead operations.

title: Simple Machines — The Lever
description: The child discovers how a lever works by experimenting with a ruler balanced on a fulcrum. This hands-on physics exploration shows how a simple machine makes it easier to lift heavy objects.
instructions:
1. 'Machines help us do work more easily. Today we learn about the LEVER — one of the simplest machines!'
2. Set up a lever: sturdy ruler on a triangular block (fulcrum).
3. Place a small heavy object (rock or can) on one end.
4. 'Push down on the other end. The heavy thing goes UP! The lever helped you lift it!'
5. Experiment: move the fulcrum closer to the heavy object. 'Is it easier or harder to lift now?'
6. Real-world levers: seesaw, bottle opener, crowbar, scissors.
7. Draw and label the parts: lever (beam), fulcrum (pivot point), load, effort.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the lever on a table. Have various heavy objects to experiment with. Display real lever examples.

slides.text: 'A LEVER is one of the oldest and simplest machines! It helps us lift heavy things. Let me show you.' Set the ruler on the triangular block.
Place a rock on one end. 'This rock is heavy. But watch!' Push down on the other end. 'The rock goes UP! The lever made it easy to lift!'
'The triangle in the middle is called the FULCRUM — the balance point. Let's move the fulcrum closer to the rock.' Try lifting again. 'Even easier!'
'Levers are everywhere! A seesaw is a lever. A bottle opener is a lever. Even scissors are two levers connected!' Show examples.

slides.prompt: Experiment: try moving the fulcrum to different positions. Where is it easiest to lift the heavy object? Where is it hardest? Draw a lever and label: beam, fulcrum, load, effort.

slides.text: 'A lever makes it easier to lift heavy things! The closer the fulcrum is to the load, the easier it is. Levers are all around us!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how a lever works, name the fulcrum, and identify at least 2 real-world levers?

parent_notes: Simple machines are a wonderful introduction to physics for young children because they can be experienced directly. The lever is the most intuitive: push down on one end, the other end goes up. The key discovery is that moving the fulcrum changes how much effort is needed — this is the concept of mechanical advantage. Let the child experiment freely with fulcrum position: closer to the load = easier to lift but less distance; farther from load = harder to lift but more distance. A seesaw is the most relatable lever for children. Archimedes said, 'Give me a lever long enough and a place to stand, and I can move the world!' Share this quote — it captures the power of simple machines beautifully.

title: Music — Introduction to Musical Notation
description: The child is introduced to the concept that music can be written down using simple symbols. Using circles and lines to represent notes, the child creates their own simple written music and plays it on percussion instruments.
instructions:
1. 'We can write WORDS on paper so people can read them. Did you know we can write MUSIC too?'
2. Show a simple notation system: big circle = long note (bang and hold), small circle = short note (quick tap).
3. Write a simple pattern: O o o O o o (long, short, short, long, short, short).
4. Clap the pattern. Then play it on an instrument.
5. Child creates their own musical notation — a sequence of big and small circles.
6. Play each other's written music!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare paper with lines for writing notation. Have instruments ready. Use big/small circles as a simple notation system.

slides.text: 'You know how we write words so people can read them? Musicians write MUSIC so people can play it! Let's learn how.'
'A BIG circle means a LONG note — bang and hooooold.' Demonstrate. 'A small circle means a short note — tap!' Demonstrate.
Write a pattern: O o o O o o. 'Let's read it! Long, short, short, long, short, short.' Clap it. Then play it on the drum.
'Now YOU write music! Make a pattern of big and small circles on your paper. Then we will play your music!'

slides.prompt: Compose your own music! Write a pattern of big (long) and small (short) circles. Make it at least 8 notes long. Then play your composition on an instrument. I will play YOUR music too!

slides.text: 'You are a COMPOSER — someone who writes music! Real composers use more complex symbols, but the idea is the same: marks on paper that become sounds.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a simple notation pattern and play it back correctly on an instrument?

parent_notes: This lesson introduces the revolutionary concept that music — sound that exists in time — can be captured in visual symbols. This is analogous to reading (sound to symbol) and deeply connects to the language curriculum. Start with just two note values (long and short) to keep it accessible. The child experiences both sides of notation: composing (writing symbols) and performing (reading symbols and producing sounds). This is powerful because the child creates something that another person can interpret — communication through music. If the child is ready, add a third symbol: an X for silence (rest). Real musical notation uses many symbols, but the concept is identical to what the child does here.

title: Table Scrubbing — Introduction
description: The child learns the complete process of scrubbing a table: preparing materials, wetting the surface, scrubbing with soap, rinsing, and drying. This complex, multi-step activity develops sequencing, concentration, and care of the environment.
instructions:
1. Present materials on a tray: basin of water, soap (bar or liquid), scrub brush, sponge, drying towel, apron.
2. Put on apron. 'We are going to SCRUB the table until it is perfectly clean!'
3. Demonstrate: dip sponge in water, squeeze, wipe the table to wet it.
4. Rub soap on the brush or table. Scrub in circles: 'Round and round, pressing firmly.'
5. Rinse: wipe soap away with clean wet sponge.
6. Dry with the towel. 'Run your hand over it — is it clean and dry?'
7. Clean up materials: empty water, rinse brush, hang towel.
materials_needed: Small table or section of table

slides.setup_instructions: Set up near a small table or on a section of the main table. Put on the apron. Protect the floor with a towel.

slides.text: 'Today we do something that takes many steps — scrubbing a table! This is real work, and when we are done, the table will be perfectly clean. First, apron on!'
Demonstrate wetting: 'Dip the sponge in water, squeeze out the extra.' Wipe the table to wet the surface. 'Now the table is ready for soap.'
Rub soap on the brush. 'Now scrub in circles!' Demonstrate circular motion with the brush. 'Press firmly. Round and round. Cover the whole table.'
'Now rinse: wet the sponge with clean water, squeeze, and wipe away ALL the soap.' Repeat until no soap remains. 'Finally, dry with the towel.'

slides.prompt: Now you scrub the table! Remember the steps: wet, soap, scrub in circles, rinse, dry. Take your time — feel the difference between the soapy surface and the clean, dry surface!

slides.text: Clean up all materials: empty water, rinse the brush and sponge, hang the towel, fold the apron. 'You scrubbed the table beautifully!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow the complete sequence (wet, soap, scrub, rinse, dry) and clean up materials?

parent_notes: Table scrubbing is one of the most complex and beloved Montessori practical life activities. It involves at least 12 sequential steps and typically takes 20-30 minutes of sustained concentration. The activity is as much about the PROCESS as the result — the child practices sequencing, bilateral coordination, and sustained focus. Many children want to repeat it immediately, finding the whole sequence deeply satisfying. The circular scrubbing motion prepares the hand for cursive writing. The sensory contrast between the wet/soapy/clean/dry surfaces engages the tactile sense. Some Montessori guides consider table scrubbing a meditative activity — the rhythmic motion and focus create a flow state. Do not rush the child through the steps.

title: Grammar Introduction — The Verb
description: The child is introduced to verbs as action words. Using the Montessori red circle symbol and physical movement, the child discovers that verbs tell us what someone DOES. Combined with nouns, the child begins to understand basic sentence structure.
instructions:
1. Review: 'A noun is a naming word. But sentences need more than names — they need ACTION!'
2. 'Stand up. Jump! Clap! Spin! These are all ACTIONS — and the words for actions are called VERBS.'
3. Write action words on cards: run, hop, sit, clap, wave, sing, read, eat.
4. Child picks a card, reads the verb, and DOES the action.
5. Show the red circle symbol: 'We use a red circle for verbs because verbs are full of ENERGY — like a ball bouncing!'
6. Combine with nouns: 'dog + runs = The dog runs.' Noun (triangle) + verb (circle) = sentence!

slides.setup_instructions: Write verbs on separate cards. Have space for the child to move. Keep the black triangles from the noun lesson handy.

slides.text: 'Last time we learned about NOUNS — naming words. But watch: CAT. Just a name. Boring! But CAT RUNS — now something is HAPPENING! The action word is called a VERB.'
'Verbs are action words! I'll prove it. Pick a card and read it.' Child reads 'jump.' 'Now DO it!' Child jumps. 'That is a verb — a DOING word!'
Continue: hop, clap, wave, spin, sit, read. Each time, the child reads and performs. 'Verbs make things HAPPEN!'
Show the red circle: 'This is the verb symbol — red and round like a bouncing ball, full of energy!' Place red circles over verbs in sentences.

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Find the NOUN (put the black triangle over it) and the VERB (put the red circle over it). Try: 'The cat sits.' 'The dog runs.' 'A bird sings.'

slides.text: 'Every sentence needs a noun AND a verb — a thing that DOES something! Noun + verb = sentence. You are learning how language works!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define a verb, identify verbs in sentences, and distinguish verbs from nouns?

parent_notes: The Montessori verb lesson is kinesthetic — the child physically performs each verb, connecting the abstract concept to bodily experience. This is why children remember it so well. The red circle symbol represents the dynamic, energetic nature of verbs (compared to the stable, solid triangle for nouns). After this lesson, play the 'verb game' throughout the day: whisper an action word and the child performs it, or the child writes action cards for you. The combination of noun + verb creates the simplest possible sentence, which is the foundation of all grammar. 'Dog runs,' 'Bird sings,' 'Fish swims' — each has a thing (noun) doing something (verb). This concrete understanding of sentence structure supports both reading comprehension and writing development.

title: Golden Beads — Subtraction Introduction
description: The child performs their first golden bead subtraction: starting with a large quantity and taking away a smaller quantity to find what remains. This concrete operation shows that subtraction means 'taking away.'
instructions:
1. 'We have learned addition — putting together. Now we learn SUBTRACTION — taking away!'
2. Build 3,846 with golden beads and number cards.
3. 'We are going to take away 1,523. First, take away 3 units from the 6 units.' Child removes 3. '3 units remain.'
4. 'Take away 2 tens from the 4 tens.' Child removes 2. '2 tens remain.'
5. 'Take away 5 hundreds from the 8 hundreds.' Child removes 5. '3 hundreds remain.'
6. 'Take away 1 thousand from the 3 thousands.' Child removes 1. '2 thousands remain.'
7. Build answer: 2,323. 'What is left after we take away is the ANSWER!'

slides.setup_instructions: Build the starting number with beads. Have a tray nearby for the beads that are taken away. Choose numbers that do NOT require exchange for this first lesson.

slides.text: 'Addition is putting together. SUBTRACTION is the opposite — taking away! Let's start with a big number and take some away.'
Build 3,846 on the mat with beads and cards. 'This is our starting number: three thousand, eight hundred, forty-six.'
'We want to take away 1,523. Start with units: take 3 units away from the 6 units.' Child removes 3. 'How many units are left? 3!'
Continue: 'Take 2 tens from the 4 tens — 2 remain. Take 5 hundreds from 8 hundreds — 3 remain. Take 1 thousand from 3 thousands — 2 remain.'

slides.prompt: Build the answer with number cards: 2,000 + 300 + 20 + 3 = 2,323! Now try: start with 4,967 and take away 2,345. What remains?

slides.text: 'Subtraction is taking away. What is left over is the answer — we call it the DIFFERENCE. You can add AND subtract with golden beads!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform golden bead subtraction without exchange, correctly removing quantities and stating the remainder?

parent_notes: This first subtraction lesson uses numbers that do not require exchange (borrowing). Each category of the number being subtracted is smaller than the corresponding category in the starting number. This allows the child to focus purely on the concept: subtraction means taking away from what you have. The physical act of removing beads from the mat is concrete and clear. Place the removed beads on a separate tray so they do not get mixed up. After finding the remainder, the child builds it with number cards. Next lesson will introduce subtraction with exchange — when you need to take away more than you have in a category and must 'borrow' from the next larger one. But today, success and understanding come first.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Resolving Conflicts Peacefully
description: The child learns a simple process for resolving disagreements peacefully: using words to express feelings, listening to the other person, and finding a solution together. This peace education lesson is central to Montessori philosophy.
instructions:
1. 'Sometimes people disagree. That is normal! The important thing is HOW we handle it.'
2. Introduce the peace process: (1) Stop and take a breath. (2) Use words: 'I feel ___ when ___.' (3) Listen to the other person. (4) Find a solution together.
3. Role play: 'Two children both want to use the red crayon.'
4. Practice 'I messages': 'I feel frustrated when I cannot use the red crayon.'
5. Practice listening: repeat back what you heard.
6. Find a solution: take turns, share, find another color.

slides.setup_instructions: Have a feelings chart visible. If you have a peace rose (a rose or flower used in Montessori peace processes), bring it out.

slides.text: 'Everyone disagrees sometimes — even best friends! That is okay. What matters is how we SOLVE the problem. Let me teach you the PEACE PROCESS.'
'Step 1: STOP. Take a deep breath. This helps your brain calm down so you can think.' Practice together: breathe in for 4, out for 4.
'Step 2: USE WORDS. Say how you feel: I feel frustrated when... I feel sad when... We use I-MESSAGES because they tell the truth without blaming.'
'Step 3: LISTEN. Let the other person talk. Repeat back what they said: You feel ___ because ___. Step 4: SOLVE IT TOGETHER. What can we do so both people are happy?'

slides.prompt: Role play: You and I both want the same book. Let's use the peace process! Stop, breathe, share feelings, listen, and find a solution. Then try another scenario!

slides.text: 'When we use words instead of actions, when we listen and solve problems together, we create PEACE. You are a peacemaker!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate the 4 steps of the peace process and use an I-message?

parent_notes: Conflict resolution is arguably the most important grace and courtesy lesson in the entire Montessori curriculum. Maria Montessori was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize three times because she believed education could create peace. The peace process taught here (stop, I-message, listen, solve) is used in Montessori classrooms worldwide. The 'peace rose' is a powerful tool: only the person holding the rose may speak, teaching respectful turn-taking. I-messages ('I feel frustrated when...') are crucial because they express feelings without blame. Practice this with real conflicts as they arise. Children who internalize this process carry it throughout their lives. This is not just a lesson — it is a life skill.

title: Read-Aloud: Enemy Pie by Derek Munson
description: Reading this humorous story about a boy who tries to get rid of his enemy by feeding him 'enemy pie,' only to discover that spending time together turns an enemy into a friend. This connects to the conflict resolution lesson.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This boy has an ENEMY. Have you ever felt that way about someone?'
2. Read the story with humor. The father's 'enemy pie' recipe requires spending a whole day being nice to your enemy!
3. Pause when the boy starts having fun: 'Wait — he is starting to enjoy being with his enemy!'
4. At the end: 'The enemy pie worked — but not the way he expected! What really happened?'
5. Discuss: 'Sometimes the people we think we do not like become our friends when we spend time with them.'
6. Connect to the peace process lesson.

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably. This is a humorous book — read with expression!

slides.text: 'This boy has an enemy — someone he does not like. His dad says he knows how to fix it: ENEMY PIE! But there is a catch...'
Read with expression and humor. When the father reveals the secret ingredient: 'You have to spend a whole day being NICE to your enemy!' The boy is horrified!
As the day progresses: 'Look — they are playing together. They are laughing! Are they still enemies?' The boy starts to worry about the pie.

slides.prompt: After reading: 'What was the REAL secret ingredient of enemy pie? Getting to know someone! Have you ever become friends with someone you did not like at first? What changed?'

slides.text: 'The best way to turn an enemy into a friend is to spend time with them and be kind. Just like we learned in our peace process — use words, listen, and find things you share.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the real lesson of enemy pie (getting to know someone turns enemies into friends)?

parent_notes: Enemy Pie pairs perfectly with the conflict resolution grace and courtesy lesson. Its humor makes a serious topic accessible: sometimes the people we think are enemies become friends when we make an effort. The father in the story is a wonderful model — he does not lecture or moralize but creates a situation where the child discovers the truth himself. This is very Montessori: set up the environment, let the child learn through experience. After reading, discuss: has the child ever changed their mind about someone? Has someone who seemed unfriendly become a friend? The recipe for 'enemy pie' (being kind and spending time together) is really the recipe for all good relationships.

title: Binomial Cube — Practice
description: The child practices assembling the binomial cube, working to build it independently by matching colors and referring to the painted pattern on the box. This three-dimensional puzzle develops spatial reasoning and prepares for algebraic concepts.
instructions:
1. 'Let's work with the binomial cube today!' Open the box.
2. Review the pieces: red cube, blue cube, and the red-black and blue-black prisms.
3. Carefully remove the top layer. Separate the pieces.
4. Rebuild the top layer by matching colors to the pattern on the box lid.
5. Remove and rebuild the bottom layer.
6. Try assembling the entire cube without looking at the lid (advanced).
7. Replace in box carefully.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the box on a mat. The painted pattern on the lid and sides serves as the control of error.

slides.text: 'The binomial cube is a beautiful 3D puzzle! Let's see if you can build it. The box lid shows the pattern for the top layer.'
Open the box. 'Carefully lift out the cube. Now separate the TOP layer — these 4 pieces.' Lay them on the mat.
'Look at the lid pattern. The red cube goes here. The red-black prism goes next to it with the black side touching. The blue-black prism here.'
'Now the bottom layer!' Separate and rebuild. 'The blue cube goes in the corner, with the matching prisms around it.'

slides.prompt: Build the entire binomial cube yourself! Use the pattern on the lid to guide you. When you have both layers, carefully stack the top on the bottom and slide it back into the box.

slides.text: 'You built the binomial cube! This puzzle is actually a math formula — someday you will learn the algebra behind it. For now, enjoy the patterns!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child assemble the binomial cube using the pattern on the box lid with minimal assistance?

parent_notes: The binomial cube represents the algebraic formula (a+b)^3, but at this stage it is presented purely as a sensorial puzzle. The child absorbs the relationships between the pieces through repeated assembly without any algebraic explanation. Years later, when they encounter the formula in algebra, they will have a deep, embodied understanding of what it means. This is the Montessori concept of indirect preparation — the sensorial experience now lays neural pathways for abstract understanding later. The color coding (red=a, blue=b, black=ab) is consistent and helps the child self-correct. Some children become very quick at assembling the cube and can do it without the lid guide — this is impressive spatial reasoning.

title: Grammar Practice — Noun and Verb in Sentences
description: The child practices identifying nouns and verbs in sentences, using the black triangle and red circle symbols. Through reading, parsing, and acting out sentences, the child deepens understanding of sentence structure.
instructions:
1. Review: 'What is a noun? A naming word. What is a verb? An action word.'
2. Prepare sentence strips with simple sentences: 'The fish swims.' 'A bird flies.' 'The boy reads.' 'A dog digs.'
3. Child reads each sentence, places black triangle over the noun and red circle over the verb.
4. 'Now act it out! What does the fish do? It swims!' Child pretends to swim.
5. Extension: child writes their own noun + verb sentences.
6. 'Every sentence needs at least one noun and one verb!'

slides.setup_instructions: Write simple sentences on strips. Cut out multiple black triangles and red circles.

slides.text: 'Let's review: nouns are NAMING words (black triangle). Verbs are ACTION words (red circle). Today we find BOTH in sentences!'
Read together: 'The fish swims.' 'Which word is the noun — the naming word? FISH!' Place black triangle. 'Which word is the verb — the action? SWIMS!' Place red circle.
Continue: 'A bird flies.' 'The boy reads.' 'A dog digs.' 'The cat sleeps.' Child identifies and marks each noun and verb.
'Let's act out each sentence! The fish swims — show me!' Child pretends to swim. 'The bird flies — flap your arms!' Physical acting reinforces the verb concept.

slides.prompt: Parse all the sentences with triangles and circles. Then write 3 sentences of your OWN! Think of a noun (person, animal, or thing) and a verb (what it does). Mark them with symbols!

slides.text: 'Every sentence in every book has nouns and verbs. Now when you read, you can spot them! Nouns tell WHAT, verbs tell what it DOES.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify nouns and verbs in at least 5 sentences and write 2 original noun-verb sentences?

parent_notes: Parsing sentences with physical symbols (triangles for nouns, circles for verbs) makes grammar concrete and visual. The child sees the structure of language laid out in front of them. Acting out sentences adds a kinesthetic dimension — the child's body experiences what the verb means. When the child writes their own sentences, they apply understanding of both parts: they need a thing (noun) and something it does (verb). At this stage, keep articles (the, a) aside — mention them briefly as 'little words that go with nouns' but do not formally teach them yet. The important insight is that every sentence needs a noun (the subject) and a verb (the predicate). This is the foundation of all sentence construction.

title: Golden Beads — Subtraction with Exchange
description: The child encounters subtraction where a category does not have enough to take away, requiring an exchange (borrowing). One ten bar is exchanged for 10 units when the units column is too small for subtraction.
instructions:
1. Build 3,542 with golden beads.
2. 'We want to take away 1,327. Start with units: take 7 from 2. But wait — we only have 2 units!'
3. 'We do not have enough units. We need to EXCHANGE! Take 1 ten bar and exchange it for 10 units.'
4. Now we have 12 units (10+2) and 3 tens (4-1). 'Take 7 from 12. That leaves 5!'
5. Continue: tens: 3-2=1. Hundreds: 5-3=2. Thousands: 3-1=2.
6. Build answer: 2,215.
7. 'We exchanged 1 ten for 10 units — that is called borrowing!'

slides.setup_instructions: Build the starting number. Choose a subtrahend that requires exchange in one category. Have extra unit beads ready for the exchange.

slides.text: 'Build 3,542 with golden beads. Now we take away 1,327. Start with units: take 7 from... wait. We only have 2 units! 7 is more than 2!'
'We need MORE units. Where can we get them? From the TENS! Take 1 ten bar and exchange it for 10 units.' Do the exchange: 1 ten bar → 10 units.
'Now we have 12 units! Can we take 7 from 12? YES! 12 minus 7 is 5 units.' Remove 7. '5 units remain. But now we only have 3 tens instead of 4.'
'Tens: 3 minus 2 = 1 ten. Hundreds: 5 minus 3 = 2 hundreds. Thousands: 3 minus 1 = 2 thousands.' Build answer: 2,215!

slides.prompt: Try: start with 4,631 and take away 2,418. You will need to exchange! Remember: if you do not have enough, go to the next bigger category and exchange.

slides.text: 'When we do not have enough to take away, we EXCHANGE from the next bigger group — just like in addition! This is called borrowing.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform subtraction with exchange in at least one category?

parent_notes: Subtraction with exchange (borrowing) is the counterpart to addition with exchange (carrying). The child discovers that when there are not enough in a category to subtract from, they can exchange 1 from the next larger category into 10 of the current category. This is the concrete experience behind 'borrowing' in the standard algorithm. The golden beads make the exchange physically visible: the child literally trades 1 ten bar for 10 unit beads. Some children initially resist breaking a ten bar apart, but once they see that 10 units IS the same as 1 ten, the exchange becomes natural. Choose problems that require exchange in only one category at first. Multiple exchanges (borrowing across several columns) can come with more practice.

title: Simple Machines — The Inclined Plane and Wheel
description: The child explores two more simple machines: the inclined plane (ramp) and the wheel and axle. Through hands-on experimentation, the child discovers how these machines make work easier in everyday life.
instructions:
1. Review the lever from last week. 'Today we meet TWO more simple machines!'
2. INCLINED PLANE (ramp): set up a board leaning on a stack of books.
3. 'Try lifting this heavy toy car straight UP to the top. Hard! Now roll it UP THE RAMP. Easier!'
4. 'A ramp spreads the work over a longer distance, making it feel lighter.'
5. WHEEL AND AXLE: show a toy car's wheels. 'Without wheels, we would have to DRAG everything!'
6. Compare: push a book across the table (friction) vs. rolling it on pencils (wheels).
7. Find ramps and wheels in the house: stairs, doorknobs, rolling carts.
materials_needed: Toy car or heavy small object
Pictures of ramps and wheels in real life

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a ramp with the board and books. Have a heavy small object to lift and roll. Line up pencils for the rolling experiment.

slides.text: 'We learned about levers. Today we meet TWO more simple machines! First: the INCLINED PLANE — we call it a RAMP.'
Set up the ramp. 'Try lifting this toy car straight UP to the top of the books. Hard work! Now... push it up the RAMP.' Child does both. 'Which was easier?'
'The ramp is longer than lifting straight up, but it makes the job EASIER! This is why we use ramps for wheelchairs, moving trucks, and skateboard parks.'
'Next: the WHEEL! Try pushing this book across the table — feel the friction? Now put pencils underneath and roll it.' The book glides! 'Wheels reduce friction!'

slides.prompt: Experiment: make the ramp steeper and less steep. Which is easier to push up? Then go on a simple machine hunt: find ramps and wheels in your house! How many can you spot?

slides.text: 'Ramps and wheels make our lives easier every day! You know THREE simple machines now: lever, ramp, and wheel. Scientists call them SIMPLE MACHINES.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how a ramp and a wheel make work easier, and find examples in the environment?

parent_notes: Simple machines are everywhere, and once children learn to identify them, they see them constantly — which is exactly the point. The inclined plane experiment is particularly vivid: lifting an object straight up requires more force than pushing it up a ramp (though the ramp requires more distance). The trade-off between force and distance is the key principle of all simple machines. The wheel demonstration with pencils under a book clearly shows friction reduction. After this lesson, go on a simple machine scavenger hunt: stairs are inclined planes, doorknobs are wheel-and-axle mechanisms, scissors are levers, screws are inclined planes wrapped around a shaft. The world becomes a physics laboratory!

title: Printmaking — Leaf Prints
description: The child creates prints using real leaves as stamps. By painting the textured side of a leaf and pressing it onto paper, the child discovers the beauty of natural patterns and the art technique of printmaking.
instructions:
1. Collect 3-5 leaves with prominent veins (maple, oak, fern fronds work well).
2. 'The back of a leaf has raised VEINS. We are going to use these as a stamp!'
3. Demonstrate: paint the veined (back) side of a leaf with a thin, even layer of paint.
4. Press the leaf paint-side down onto paper. Press firmly and evenly. Peel off carefully.
5. 'Look at the beautiful print! You can see every vein!'
6. Create a composition: overlap leaves, use different colors, make patterns.

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table. Choose leaves with clear veins. Have paint in small amounts on a plate or palette.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use REAL LEAVES to make art prints! Feel the back of this leaf — can you feel the raised lines? Those are VEINS that carried water through the leaf.'
Demonstrate: 'Paint a thin, even layer on the veiny side. Not too thick or the veins will fill in!' Show even brushstrokes.
'Now carefully flip the leaf over and press it on the paper. Press every part — use your fingers to push down gently.' Then peel the leaf away slowly.
'Look at the print! You can see every vein and the leaf's shape perfectly! Try another leaf, or the same one with a different color.'

slides.prompt: Make prints with all your leaves! Try different colors, overlap prints, create a pattern or a tree shape. Each leaf makes a unique print — like a fingerprint for trees!

slides.text: Let prints dry. 'Printmaking is an ancient art form. You used nature itself as your printing tool! Each leaf is unique, and each print is a work of art.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child apply paint to a leaf and create a clear print showing vein detail?

parent_notes: Leaf printing connects art, science (botany), and the natural world beautifully. The child sees the leaf's structure (veins, shape, edges) in a new way because the print reveals details they might not notice just by looking. Different leaves produce dramatically different prints — compare an oak leaf to a fern frond. The key technique is paint thickness: too much paint fills the veins, too little gives a faint print. Experiment together! This is also a wonderful seasonal activity — fall leaves produce stunning warm-colored prints. The prints make beautiful cards, wrapping paper, or journal covers. Some children become fascinated by leaf identification through this process: 'Which tree does this leaf come from?'

title: Care of Environment Review — Choosing a Job
description: The child reviews all care of environment skills learned in weeks 10-12 (flower arranging, plant watering, sweeping, dusting, window washing, table scrubbing) and chooses one to perform independently as their daily responsibility.
instructions:
1. 'This week you learned so many ways to take care of our space! Let's review them all.'
2. List together: flower arranging, watering plants, sweeping, dusting, window washing, table scrubbing.
3. 'Which jobs do you enjoy most? Which do you feel most confident doing?'
4. 'Choose ONE job that will be YOUR daily or weekly responsibility.'
5. The child performs their chosen job independently while you observe.
6. Create a simple care of environment chart with the child's chosen responsibilities.
materials_needed: Materials for the child's chosen job

slides.setup_instructions: Have materials available for all previously taught care of environment activities. The child will choose one to perform.

slides.text: 'You have learned so many ways to care for our home! Let's list them: flower arranging, plant watering, sweeping, dusting, window washing, table scrubbing.'
'Which ones do you enjoy? Which ones are you really good at? It is important to choose a job you WANT to do, because you will do it regularly.'
'Today you will choose your RESPONSIBILITY — a job that is yours. You do not need to be asked; you do it because it needs doing and it is YOUR job.'
'Let's make a chart! We will write your job and mark each day you complete it.' Create a simple tracking chart together.

slides.prompt: Choose your responsibility and do it NOW — completely on your own, from getting materials to cleaning up. Then decorate your responsibility chart with your name and your job.

slides.text: 'You have a REAL job now — one that matters to our whole family. Taking care of your environment is taking care of yourself and the people you love.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child choose and independently complete a care of environment task from start to finish, including cleanup?

parent_notes: This lesson transforms isolated skills into genuine responsibility. Montessori believed that children NEED meaningful work — not busywork, but real contributions to the household. When a child knows that watering the plants is THEIR job, they develop a sense of purpose and belonging. The responsibility chart provides accountability without nagging. Let the child decorate it and post it prominently. Do NOT redo their work if it is imperfect — this communicates that their contribution is not good enough. Instead, occasionally work alongside them, modeling technique. Rotate responsibilities monthly or quarterly so the child builds a full repertoire of skills. Some children take this very seriously and add additional responsibilities on their own.

title: Reading Longer Phrases and Simple Stories
description: The child reads longer phrases and very simple stories using all known phonics skills: single letter sounds, phonograms (sh, ch, th), and sight words. This is a significant reading milestone — the transition from word and sentence reading to story reading.
instructions:
1. Prepare a simple story on separate strips (one sentence per strip):
   'The red fish swam in the pond.'
   'A big frog sat on a thick log.'
   'The frog said, Splash! and got the fish wet.'
   'The fish was not glad.'
   'Then the frog and the fish had a chat.'
   'Now the fish and the frog are pals.'
2. Child reads each strip in order.
3. Retell: 'What happened in the story?'
4. Illustrate the story.
5. Celebrate: the child just read their first story!
materials_needed: Story sentence strips (handwritten in clear print)

slides.setup_instructions: Write the story on separate strips in large, clear print. Use mostly decodable words plus known sight words (the, a, was, said, are).

slides.text: 'Today is a very special day. You are going to read a STORY — not just words, not just sentences, but a whole STORY with a beginning, middle, and end!'
Place the first strip: 'Read this sentence.' The child reads: 'The red fish swam in the pond.' 'Great! Now the next part of the story...'
Continue strip by strip. Let the child work through each word. For phonograms (th, sh, ch), they should recognize them now. Sight words may need a reminder.
After reading all strips: 'You just read a whole STORY! Tell me what happened.' The child retells in their own words — this shows comprehension.

slides.prompt: Draw a picture of the story — the fish, the frog, the pond, the log. Write a title for your picture. If you want, write a sentence about what might happen NEXT!

slides.text: 'You read a STORY from beginning to end! You are a real READER now. There are millions of stories waiting for you — and you have the skills to read them!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a 6-sentence simple story and retell the main events?

parent_notes: Reading a complete story — however simple — is a transformative milestone. The child shifts from decoding isolated words to following a narrative. This requires holding multiple sentences in memory, tracking cause and effect, and understanding character motivations. The story should be mostly phonetically decodable with just a few sight words (the, a, was, said, are). Write it on strips so each sentence feels manageable. The retelling is crucial: it demonstrates comprehension, not just decoding. If the child can retell the story, they understood it. The illustration adds a creative response. Celebrate this moment — the child has crossed the threshold from 'learning to read' to 'reading.' From here, the path leads to simple phonetic readers, then early chapter books, then the entire world of literature.

title: Golden Beads — Subtraction with Exchange Practice
description: The child practices golden bead subtraction with exchange, building fluency. Multiple problems reinforce the sequence: start with a quantity, check if you have enough to take away, exchange if needed, remove the amount, and find the remainder.
instructions:
1. 'Let's practice subtraction with exchange. Remember: if you do not have enough, exchange from the next bigger group!'
2. Problem 1: 5,432 - 2,218 (exchange needed in units: 2-8, exchange 1 ten→10 units, now 12-8=4)
3. Problem 2: 3,714 - 1,536 (exchange in units: 4-6, AND tens: 0-3 after exchange!)
4. For each problem, child works through systematically.
5. Verify answers together.
6. Child creates their own subtraction problem.

slides.setup_instructions: Build the starting number. Have the bead bank ready for exchanges. Choose problems that require exchange in 1-2 categories.

slides.text: 'Subtraction with exchange practice! Remember the steps: can I take away? If yes, do it! If no, EXCHANGE first, then take away.'
Problem 1: 5,432 - 2,218. Build 5,432. 'Start with units: take 8 from 2. Oh! Not enough. Exchange 1 ten for 10 units. Now: 12-8=4!'
'Tens: we had 3, but gave 1 away = 2 tens. Take 1 away: 1 ten left. Hundreds: 4-2=2. Thousands: 5-2=3.' Answer: 3,214.
Problem 2: 3,714 - 1,536. 'Units: 4-6? Not enough! Exchange from tens. Tens: 1, give 1 away = 0 tens. Now 14-6=8 units. Tens: 0-3? Not enough again!'

slides.prompt: Finish problem 2 (exchange from hundreds for tens!). Then make up YOUR own subtraction problem. Choose a big starting number and subtract a smaller one. Can you solve it?

slides.text: 'You can do addition AND subtraction with the golden beads — even with exchanges! You are working with numbers in the THOUSANDS. That is incredible!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently perform subtraction with exchange, handling at least one exchange correctly?

parent_notes: Subtraction with multiple exchanges is the most complex golden bead operation at this level. When both units AND tens require exchange, the child must work through a chain of exchanges — this is exactly what happens in the standard written algorithm when you borrow across multiple columns. Some children find this cascading exchange confusing at first. If so, break it into explicit steps: (1) Check units — enough? No → exchange from tens. (2) Check tens — enough now? No → exchange from hundreds. (3) Now work through each subtraction. This step-by-step approach builds confidence. Creating their own problems is motivating and develops number sense — the child learns that the starting number must be larger than the number being subtracted.

title: Celebrations — Easter and Nowruz (Spring Celebrations)
description: The child learns about two spring celebrations from different cultures: Easter (Christian tradition) and Nowruz (Persian/Iranian New Year). Both celebrate renewal, new life, and the arrival of spring, showing how different cultures mark the same seasonal change.
instructions:
1. 'Spring is a time of new life! Many cultures around the world celebrate spring. Today we learn about two celebrations.'
2. EASTER: 'In the Christian tradition, Easter celebrates new life and hope. People decorate eggs, which are symbols of new life.'
3. Show pictures of Easter eggs, egg hunts, spring flowers.
4. NOWRUZ: 'In Iran and many other countries, the New Year begins on the first day of spring! It is called Nowruz — NOW-rooz.'
5. Show the Haft-sin table: 7 items starting with 's' that symbolize health, beauty, patience, etc.
6. Compare: both celebrate spring, new beginnings, and family togetherness.
materials_needed: Pictures of Nowruz celebrations and Haft-sin table

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures of both celebrations. Have the globe ready to locate relevant countries.

slides.text: 'When spring comes after winter, people all over the world CELEBRATE! Plants grow, animals are born, and the days get longer. Let's learn about two spring celebrations.'
'EASTER is celebrated by Christians around the world. Eggs are a symbol of new life! People decorate eggs, have egg hunts, and celebrate with family.' Show pictures.
'NOWRUZ means New Day! In Iran and many countries, the New Year starts on the first day of spring!' Find Iran on the globe. 'Families set a special table called Haft-sin with 7 items.'
'Both celebrations are about SPRING — new life, new beginnings, hope! Different cultures, same beautiful idea.'

slides.prompt: If you have an egg, decorate it to celebrate spring! Draw symbols of new life: flowers, baby animals, sunshine. Or draw a Haft-sin table with 7 special items.

slides.text: 'People everywhere celebrate spring — the season of new life. Easter and Nowruz are two beautiful ways different cultures welcome the new season!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name both celebrations, explain what each celebrates, and identify the theme of spring/new life?

parent_notes: Comparing celebrations from different cultures around a shared theme (spring/renewal) is a powerful way to build both cultural literacy and appreciation for diversity. The child sees that while customs differ, the human response to seasonal change is universal. Present both celebrations with equal respect and enthusiasm. If your family celebrates Easter, the Nowruz information adds a global perspective. If your family celebrates Nowruz, the Easter information adds breadth. If your family celebrates neither, both are presented as fascinating cultural traditions. The Haft-sin table is particularly interesting: seven items beginning with the letter 's' in Persian, each symbolizing something important (health, beauty, patience, sunrise, love, fertility, medicine). This connects to language concepts!

title: Read-Aloud: Officer Buckle and Gloria by Peggy Rathmann
description: Reading 'Officer Buckle and Gloria' by Peggy Rathmann, a Caldecott Medal winner about a police officer whose safety tips become exciting when his dog Gloria acts them out behind his back.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Who do you see? What do you think the dog is doing?'
2. Read aloud — the humor comes from what Gloria does behind Officer Buckle's back.
3. Encourage the child to look carefully at the illustrations for Gloria's antics.
4. Discuss: 'Why did people start paying attention? Did Officer Buckle know what Gloria was doing?'
5. Talk about teamwork: 'They were better together, weren't they?'
6. Share a safety tip of your own!

slides.subheading: Officer Buckle and Gloria by Peggy Rathmann

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a Caldecott Medal winner!

slides.text: Cover: 'This is Officer Buckle and his dog Gloria. What do you think Gloria is doing behind him?'
Read with a straight, serious voice for Officer Buckle. The humor is in Gloria's physical comedy — point out what she's doing!
Discuss: 'Why is this story funny? What happened when Gloria stayed home? Why do they need each other?'

slides.prompt: Make up your own safety tip! Draw a poster with a safety rule, just like Officer Buckle's stars send him.

slides.text: 'Officer Buckle's best safety tip: Always stick with your buddy! They were a great team.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Officer Buckle and Gloria worked better as a team?

parent_notes: This Caldecott winner teaches teamwork, friendship, and the value of partnership. The visual humor (Gloria acting out tips behind Officer Buckle) develops visual literacy. It connects to Montessori grace and courtesy lessons about safety and working together. A wonderful read-aloud that children request again and again.
